information:
According to Taiwo Oyedele, the Chairman of the Presidential Committee on Fiscal Policy and Tax Reforms, the proposed Tax Reform Bill includes a provision to exempt real estate transactions from Value Added Tax (VAT). Official statements indicate the bill also contains exemptions on stamp duties for rents below N10 million per month and capital gains tax on the sale of dwelling houses. The stated purpose of these reforms is to reduce the tax burden on the construction and real estate sectors, thereby lowering housing costs and improving affordability for low-income earners.

As of late April 2025, reports indicated that the Tax Reform Bill had been passed by the Nigerian House of Representatives and was awaiting approval from the Senate before requiring presidential assent. Taiwo Oyedele, Chairman of the Presidential Tax Reform Committee, had stated in January 2025 that the bills were expected to be passed into law in the first quarter of 2025, with implementation scheduled to begin on July 1, 2025. The Q1 2025 deadline for passage has been missed.

The proposed VAT exemption has received public support from Ahmed Dangiwa, the Minister of Housing and Urban Development, as well as from industry groups like the Council of Registered Builders of Nigeria (CORBON) and the Housing Development Advocacy Network (HDAN). However, the broader tax reform package faces opposition from labor unions. The President of the Trade Union Congress (TUC), Festus Osifo, described the bills as 'anti-worker,' with union objections focusing on provisions such as the minimum taxable income and the proposed scrapping of the Tertiary Education Trust Fund (TETFUND).

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — absent further legislative action and presidential assent, real estate transactions remain subject to VAT under current law.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The Senate slows or amends the Tax Reform Bill, triggering a conference process that pushes final passage past late June; or the Senate strips the VAT exemption; or the bill passes too late for transmission and presidential assent before July 1. Labor-union pushback on other provisions could also stall the package.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The Senate passes the House version (or swiftly harmonizes differences) in May or early June, retains the VAT exemption on real estate transactions, and transmits the bill promptly. President Tinubu—whose administration initiated the reform—assents before July 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale:
Key facts: The House reportedly passed the Tax Reform Bill in late April 2025; the Senate’s approval and presidential assent remain. The bill includes a VAT exemption for real estate transactions and has explicit support from the administration (via the Presidential Committee on Fiscal Policy and Tax Reforms) and relevant stakeholders in housing. Implementation was targeted for July 1, 2025, though an earlier Q1 passage goal was missed. There is organized labor opposition to parts of the broader package, which could slow or complicate Senate action. 

Why the probability isn’t higher: Time is short, and Nigeria’s legislative process requires Senate passage, possible harmonization if versions differ, and presidential assent. Labor resistance to other elements of the package could divert or delay floor time, or force amendments that require conference. Any slippage into late June raises operational risk of missing the July 1 cutoff, even if the bill eventually passes.

Why the probability isn’t lower: This is an administration-backed reform with a clear announced go-live date (July 1). The House passage is a strong signal of momentum. The VAT exemption for real estate is politically palatable compared to other contentious provisions and could be retained as a pro-housing measure. The Senate leadership is generally aligned with the presidency, and executive-priority fiscal bills often move relatively quickly when prioritized.

What would move me up: Credible reporting that the Senate has scheduled and advanced the bill through committee, a second/third reading date on the Order Paper, indications the Senate will adopt the House version with minimal changes, or statements from Senate leadership prioritizing passage this month. A rapid presidential assent commitment would also raise odds.

What would move me down: Signals of significant Senate pushback or referral for extended committee work, reports of contentious amendments requiring lengthy harmonization, credible threats of strikes or broader political impasses that disrupt sittings, or reports that the VAT exemption is being carved out or deferred from the main package.

Summary of assistant’s input used: The House has passed the bill; Senate approval and assent are pending. The VAT exemption is explicitly included and has support from housing officials and industry groups. Broader package faces labor-union opposition. Target implementation is July 1, 2025. These factors jointly suggest better-than-even odds but meaningful timing risk.
